instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.PLT_RESET: What is PLT_RESET? PLT_RESET stands for platform reset. When this is asserted the machine will not POST. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Some signs of oxidation in the <CHIP>U2600</CHIP> region.
Voltage: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.60; <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.43V; <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 0v; <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> 0v; <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET</SIGNAL> 0v; <SIGNAL>PP3V_S0</SIGNAL> 0v

Replaces <CHIP>U2600</CHIP>, but <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> stands at 0.78V.

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
So you have short; cannot expect to start the board.

" Replaces <CHIP>U2600</CHIP> "
Did you really replace the PCH???
Or was <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>, maybe...
